INTRODUCTION:
In accordance with provisions of Title 40 Code of Federal Regulations, Part 68 of the Clean Air Act Amendments, the Knoxville Utilities Board¿s (KUB¿s) Risk Management Plan (RMP) is an integrated approach to identify and manage the hazards posed by an accidental chlorine release. KUB¿S RMP is a unified program that integrates technologies, procedures and best management practices.  All applicable regulations, as required by EPA¿s Chemical Accident Prevention ¿ 40 CFR Part 68, are addressed in this Plan. The prevention program is based on the following key elements:

High level training for operators,
Effective preventive maintenance program,
Use of state of the art process and safety equipment,
Use of accurate and effective operating procedures, written with participation from the operators,
Performance of a process hazard analysis of equipment and procedures, and
Implementation of an effective auditing and inspection program.

FACILITY INFORMATION & REGULATED SUBSTANCES
 Facility ID# 1000-0009-5933
Loves Creek Wastewater Treatment Plant is an extended aeration, ¿activated sludge¿ wastewater facility with a maximum dry weather flow of 10 MGD. The maximum chlorine storage capacity at this facility is 14,000 pounds.

OFF-SITE CONSEQUENCE ANALYSIS
Each hazard assessment consisted of worst-case and alternative scenarios in order to evaluate the potential impacts of accidental releases of chlorine on the public health and environment. 

Worst Case Release Scenario 
Loves Creek uses chlorine in one (1) ton cylinders; therefore the worst-case scenario was based on the assumption that approximately 2000 pounds of chlorine would be released. All calculations for air dispersion modeling were  performed with RMP Comp Version 1.06 and results were mapped by using Landviewer 2000.  The worst-case scenario was evaluated at release duration of 10 minutes and at a release rate of 110 pounds/minute.  Air dispersion modeling resulted in a distance to endpoint of 0.9 mil

es.  Complete details are shown on the maps included in the Off Site Consequence Analysis section of the Plan.

Alternative Release Scenario 
KUB¿s process hazard analysis (PHA) indicated a chlorine release would most likely occur due to a failure in the chlorination system piping, therefore modeling for the alternative scenario was based on this assumption. The chlorine scrubber located at this plant was taken into consideration as active mitigation when conducting the alternative scenario. All calculations for the air dispersion modeling were performed with RMP Comp Version 1.06 and results were mapped by using Landviewer 2000.  The alternative scenario was evaluated at release duration of 10 minutes and at a release rate of 1630 pounds/minute. Air dispersion modeling resulted in a distance to endpoint of 0.5 miles.  Complete details are shown on the maps included in the Off Site Consequence Analysis section of the Plan.

FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY
In addition to the off-site consequence analysis, a five (5) year accident history was compiled for Loves Creek.  In the past five years there have been no incidents related to chlorine releases.

PREVENTION PROGRAM
KUB¿s accidental release prevention program is based upon OSHA¿s Process Safety Management Standard, 29 CFR 1910.119 and addresses key prevention elements tailored to our facility's operations. The Plan, in its entirety, can be reviewed in Plant Operations and in Technical Services. In accordance with the Process Safety Management provisions incorporated into the Risk Management Program, KUB promotes prevention programs in each of the major areas listed below: 

Management System
Employee Training
Mechanical IntegritY
Pre-startup Safety Review
Management of Change
Process Hazard Analysis
Process Safety Information
Standard Operating Procedures 
Compliance Audits
Incident Investigation

ACTIVE MITIGATION SYSTEMS
The chlorine scrubber system is a once-through, three-stage absorption system designed to contain

and safely evacuate a major chlorine leak while maintaining toxic vapor emissions below the Uniform Fire Code requirement of 1/2 the IDLH (immediately dangerous to life and health) value at all times.  To accomplish this, the scrubber removes >99.99% of the toxic vapor in the air while maintaining a negative pressure in the chlorine storage room.  The scrubber system consists of  three horizontal cross-flow packed bed sections. The caustic storage tank is an integral part of the system and is located below the scrubber adsorber sections. The recirculation pump pulls caustic solution from the storage tank and circulates it through the 3 stages, allowing the vapor-laden gases to be absorbed into the caustic and discharging vapor-free air through the stack.  Other safeguards in the system to prevent an accidental release are the use of a chlorine vapor detector, exhaust fans and emergency alarms.

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM
KUB¿s Emergency Response Program is based upon the Chlorine Institute¿s ¿Pamphlet 64 - Emergency Response Plans for Chlorine Facilities¿ and is designed to address the specific emergency needs associated with a chlorine leak. Even though Loves Creek Plant has active mitigation systems to minimize the likelihood of a release, KUB has a comprehensive emergency response plan that is complete, up-to-date and supplemented with emergency response training and drills for employees. KUB¿s Plan has been submitted to and reviewed by the City of Knoxville Local Emergency Response Committee (LEPC). In the event of an off-site release, the Plan prepares KUB and the Community for a response to, and mitigation of, accidental chlorine releases in order to limit the severity of such releases and their impact on both public health and environment.

PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY
KUB has recently implemented  a work management system called the Mincom Information Management System (MIMS).  Use of this system will help assure that all chlorine feed systems, includin

g emergency monitoring systems, are properly maintained.  Preventive maintenance work orders will be generated automatically and routed to the designated crew.  In addition MIMS will easily track and record the use of all KUB equipment (trucks, lab equipment, chlorine cylinder repair kits, emergency response equipment) and schedule service appointments periodically to ensure that employees are using the most reliable equipment for each task.

The visual workplace (5S) is one of the fundamental techniques KUB has adopted in a an effort to promote a continuous improvement philosophy. Visual workplace 5 -S provides a method by which employees improve workplace safety, reduce waste, simplify work processes, improve equipment maintenance and troubleshooting, and ensure continuous improvement.  Using the 5-S methodology,  the employees transform their work areas by use of easy to access visual systems based on key 5-S concepts:

-Sort (Organization) 
·Simplify (Orderliness) 
·Shine (Cleanliness) 
·Standardize 
·Sustain (Self Discipline) 

One of the most innovative safety approaches in KUB¿s new 2-year safety plan is the appointment of a KUB-wide Safety Team that will utilize the Dupont ¿STOP¿ behavioral safety program. The members of the Safety Team will work with department managers, supervisors and employees to standardize departmental safety programs, coordinate resources, and communicate safety goals and initiatives.
